lines.text: Enter HOTSPUR, WORCESTER, and DOUGLAS

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: Well said, my noble Scot: if speaking truth In this fine age were not thought flattery, Such attribution should the Douglas have, As not a soldier of this season's stamp Should go so general current through the world. By God, I cannot flatter; I do defy The tongues of soothers; but a braver place In my heart's love hath no man than yourself: Nay, task me to my word; approve me, lord.

lines.speaker: earl of douglas
lines.text: Thou art the king of honour: No man so potent breathes upon the ground But I will beard him.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: Do so, and 'tis well. What letters hast thou there?--I can but thank you.
Enter a Messenger with letters

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: These letters come from your father.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: Letters from him! why comes he not himself?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: He cannot come, my lord; he is grievous sick.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: 'Zounds! how has he the leisure to be sick In such a rustling time? Who leads his power? Under whose government come they along?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: His letters bear his mind, not I, my lord.

lines.speaker: earl of worcester
lines.text: I prithee, tell me, doth he keep his bed?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: He did, my lord, four days ere I set forth; And at the time of my departure thence He was much fear'd by his physicians.

lines.speaker: earl of worcester
lines.text: I would the state of time had first been whole Ere he by sickness had been visited: His health was never better worth than now.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: Sick now! droop now! this sickness doth infect The very life-blood of our enterprise; 'Tis catching hither, even to our camp. He writes me here, that inward sickness-- And that his friends by deputation could not So soon be drawn, nor did he think it meet To lay so dangerous and dear a trust On any soul removed but on his own. Yet doth he give us bold advertisement, That with our small conjunction we should on, To see how fortune is disposed to us; For, as he writes, there is no quailing now. Because the king is certainly possess'd Of all our purposes. What say you to it?

lines.speaker: earl of worcester
lines.text: Your father's sickness is a maim to us.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: A perilous gash, a very limb lopp'd off: And yet, in faith, it is not; his present want Seems more than we shall find it: were it good To set the exact wealth of all our states All at one cast? to set so rich a main On the nice hazard of one doubtful hour? It were not good; for therein should we read The very bottom and the soul of hope, The very list, the very utmost bound Of all our fortunes.

lines.speaker: earl of douglas
lines.text: 'Faith, and so we should; Where now remains a sweet reversion: We may boldly spend upon the hope of what Is to come in: A comfort of retirement lives in this.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: A rendezvous, a home to fly unto. If that the devil and mischance look big Upon the maidenhead of our affairs.

lines.speaker: earl of worcester
lines.text: But yet I would your father had been here. The quality and hair of our attempt Brooks no division: it will be thought By some, that know not why he is away, That wisdom, loyalty and mere dislike Of our proceedings kept the earl from hence: And think how such an apprehension May turn the tide of fearful faction And breed a kind of question in our cause; For well you know we of the offering side Must keep aloof from strict arbitrement, And stop all sight-holes, every loop from whence The eye of reason may pry in upon us: This absence of your father's draws a curtain, That shows the ignorant a kind of fear Before not dreamt of.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: You strain too far. I rather of his absence make this use: It lends a lustre and more great opinion, A larger dare to our great enterprise, Than if the earl were here; for men must think, If we without his help can make a head To push against a kingdom, with his help We shall o'erturn it topsy-turvy down. Yet all goes well, yet all our joints are whole.

lines.speaker: earl of douglas
lines.text: As heart can think: there is not such a word Spoke of in Scotland as this term of fear.
Enter SIR RICHARD VERNON

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: My cousin Vernon, welcome, by my soul.

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: Pray God my news be worth a welcome, lord. The Earl of Westmoreland, seven thousand strong, Is marching hitherwards; with him Prince John.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: No harm: what more?

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: And further, I have learn'd, The king himself in person is set forth, Or hitherwards intended speedily, With strong and mighty preparation.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: He shall be welcome too. Where is his son, The nimble-footed madcap Prince of Wales, And his comrades, that daff'd the world aside, And bid it pass?

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: All furnish'd, all in arms; All plumed like estridges that with the wind Baited like eagles having lately bathed; Glittering in golden coats, like images; As full of spirit as the month of May, And gorgeous as the sun at midsummer; Wanton as youthful goats, wild as young bulls. I saw young Harry, with his beaver on, His cuisses on his thighs, gallantly arm'd Rise from the ground like feather'd Mercury, And vaulted with such ease into his seat, As if an angel dropp'd down from the clouds, To turn and wind a fiery Pegasus And witch the world with noble horsemanship.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: No more, no more: worse than the sun in March, This praise doth nourish agues. Let them come: They come like sacrifices in their trim, And to the fire-eyed maid of smoky war All hot and bleeding will we offer them: The mailed Mars shall on his altar sit Up to the ears in blood. I am on fire To hear this rich reprisal is so nigh And yet not ours. Come, let me taste my horse, Who is to bear me like a thunderbolt Against the bosom of the Prince of Wales: Harry to Harry shall, hot horse to horse, Meet and ne'er part till one drop down a corse. O that Glendower were come!

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: There is more news: I learn'd in Worcester, as I rode along, He cannot draw his power this fourteen days.

lines.speaker: earl of douglas
lines.text: That's the worst tidings that I hear of yet.

lines.speaker: worcester
lines.text: Ay, by my faith, that bears a frosty sound.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: What may the king's whole battle reach unto?

lines.speaker: vernon
lines.text: To thirty thousand.

lines.speaker: hotspur
lines.text: Forty let it be: My father and Glendower being both away, The powers of us may serve so great a day Come, let us take a muster speedily: Doomsday is near; die all, die merrily.

lines.speaker: earl of douglas
lines.text: Talk not of dying: I am out of fear Of death or death's hand for this one-half year.
Exeunt
